newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African political killings drop to year low.
newsitem.headline: S.African political killings drop to year low.

text.p: The number of South Africans killed in political violence dropped to its lowest level in a year, the independent Human Rights Committee said on Monday.
"Fifty-seven people were killed in political violence (in January), the lowest monthly total since January 1996," the HRC said in its monthly report. The previous lowest figure was 55.
The 18 politically related killings in the volatile KwaZulu-Natal province, which is home to nine million Zulus, had dropped far below the provincial monthly average of 41, the report said.

The HRC attributed the drop to a heavy security presence in the Indian Ocean coastal province, concerted probes into political massacres and a fragile peace agreement between President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress and the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party.
Fighting in the multi-billion dollar taxi industry accounted for 15 of the 57 deaths, the report said.
"This marks a decrease for the fourth consecutive month," the HRC said. It warned the drop could be a temporary lull in an industry where drivers and owners fight for limited routes and passengers.
Two people were killed in northern KwaZulu-Natal on Monday when rival groups armed with AK-47 semi-automatic assault rifles and handguns attacked each other at a taxi rank in Kranskop, police said.
One of those killed was believed to be an innocent bystander, the police said.
The HRC figures show 981 people were killed in political violence across South Africa last year.
